author: jeffghome2020
title: CardanoOutreach - Africa Focus
description: We have difficulty reaching African Developers due to language gaps. We cannot currently meet with most African students and professors to facilitate education and oboarding to the ecosystem.

f6_assessments.q0:
The title of the proposal "CardanoOutreach - Africa Focus" , suggested that Cardano ecosystem will be promoted in Africa , which falls under the goal of this challenge  but the solution to "hire local African speaking developers to promote our educational program seems" does not really solve the problem effectively as the team could have done that without hiring an African based developers.

The impact describe in the solution does not really mention the impact the cardano ecosystem will benefit from this proposal. Overall , this is a good proposal and a little rewriting  would have a 5 star.
f6_assessments.q1: The plan is not well presented, The team did not present how long it will take them to achieve this goal , No milestone.  No key metrics are provided, no actionable steps to aid great feasibility. there is no clear milestones for 1, 3 and 6 month . But the Team experience is great for the implementation of the project
f6_assessments.q2:
The team said they will report to Catalyst via Coordinator which is great.
It would be nice to have a roadmap and metrics to monitor the number of engaged, number of referrals to Catalyst by the hired students.

The Risks and key challenges of this project was provided but the team did not include how they will mitigate the risk mention to enhance the success of the project.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposers want to reach out to the African professors and students so as to educate them on Cardano and onboarding them to the ecosystem. The proposers have funded projects from fund 4,6,7 and 8.

The requested budget is USD4500 for the hire of two persons based in South Africa, Egypt, Nigeria, Kenya and Morocco where the population of developers and computer science students is the highest. The reason for this engagement is that the hired personnel will help deliver the education programs to the target audience in the local language understood by the local audience. The proposers are in Canada. The budget requested for is a two month's pay for each of the local hires.

The proposers reckon that there is a large pool of talents in Africa, to tap into the pool requires mitigation of the language barrier and the local hires therefore are required. If the proposal takes off and is successful, there is a great impact on the Cardano ecosystem by more adoption of the Cardano, getting more people willing to contribute their efforts, attracting more developers, and may increase job opportunities in Africa.

Without looking into the negative factors affecting this proposal, I would agree that this proposal effectively addresses the challenge
f6_assessments.q1:
The main task of this proposal is to hire 2 locals who will deliver (in the African local languages?). My understanding is that most of the African universities are delivering education in English, French, Spanish, Portuguese and Afrikaans. The countries listed in the proposal as I know are mostly in English.

I therefore disagree that it is highly likely this proposal will be implemented successfully.
f6_assessments.q2: Perhaps I have failed to clearly understand the project plan.  It is my view that the hiring of locals in Africa to deliver educational program (in the local language) to computer science students may not seem necessary, as the students are educated in English. For this reason, I disagree that the information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a very interesting proposal, language is a major barrier hindering the progress of the adoption of the Cardano blockchain in Africa. I love the fact that this proposal has identified a number of countries in Africa (South Africa, Egypt, Nigeria, Kenya and Morocco) with the highest potential of producing developers and has decided to tap into this field to onboard them to project catalyst, to train them to deliver the content of this project in their own languages to students and professors in their area. This project is in agreement with the main factors of the Grow Africa, Grow Cardano challenge. This is an already ongoing project, the team now wants to onboard two new African-speaking developers to help promote their educational program to the various countries listed above. This will thus widen the scope of onboarding more Africans to the Cardano community since content (which speaks about Cardano, Cardano Foundation, Emurgo, and Project Catalyst, as well as demonstrating successful projects like Minswap, Cornucopias, and Paribus) will be coming from people who speak their language and are familiar to them.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team lead provides an easy plan to follow. Though no specific timelines are given, it looks simple to implement. Since the team is already established, the introduction of two new members wouldn't be a problem. The plan of the project is to hire two educators for two months to train the new developers on the program content. The budget is also quite simple, it entails the remuneration packages for just the educators and the project lead. The members of the team are well listed with their various qualifications and experiences, with most already members of the catalyst community. Their emails and contact has also been provided for easy verification of their identities. 
With the experience of the team and the success of their previous funded programs, and the simplicity of the plan, I see no barrier hindering the success of this project
f6_assessments.q2:
The most interesting aspect of this stage is how the team plans to report the progress of work, and also track referrals into the catalyst community through attendance of their programs. There is a plan to develop a feedback mechanism to help track new members who are referred to the catalyst community to help track their progress in the community and also develop a better communication system. I believe this is a great initiative as it will help greatly measure the success of this program and also keep taps on new members. 
The KPIs stated are easy to understand and be used to track progress. The budget presents minimal risk to the community, and the plan shows great promise of success if well implemanted.

f6_assessments.q0:
[Disclaimer: The proposer has submitted 2 proposals that are related to hiring local Cardano developers/community members (in Africa and in China) to expand their past funded project’s scope. These proposals are very similar in their goal structure. As a result, the assessments for this set of proposals will also be similar]

The premise of this proposal is quite simple. They have a project that has been funded in past Fund regarding raising the awareness of Cardano and they want to bring the project to Africa. To do this, they need to hire 2 educators that can speak Afro Asiatic language to deliver their program to students and professors in major African country (e.g. South Africa, Egypt, etc.). I think the idea is acceptable and aligned with the challenge brief which is to grow Cardano’s outreach and adoption in Africa. However, one thing that is lacking from this proposal (in my view) is the discussion regarding the challenge of recruiting these local educators that not only can speak the specified language but also has the sufficient knowledge about Cardano. This challenge was touched upon in the proposal however, there were no further explanation on how this will be overcome (i.e. the sites or method they will use to recruit these talents). Regardless, I think the proposal is still acceptable and can add value to the previous project.
f6_assessments.q1: The project is a continuation of a funded project so the team should have the ability to carry out a similar objective, just in a different area. The budget has been broken down well detailing the monthly salary for the educators as well as compensation for the project leader to coordinate the project. The roadmap was adequate in explaining the plan since it’s pretty simple in term of its implementation however, an explanation regarding the schedule and number of program that will be delivered by the hired educators in the span of 2 months would’ve been ideal. As mentioned before, the proposer’s plan for recruiting these educators should also be explained.
f6_assessments.q2: The KPIs chosen for the project are number of students participating on each presentation and number of referrals to Catalyst, which are relevant metrics to measure the project performance, as well as being quantitatively measurable. Additionally, the proposer will provide regular reports (note: frequency not mentioned) to Catalyst that will include the new recruits and a separate wallet will be made for this fund meaning that the project can be audited clearly.

f6_assessments.q0: In terms of impact, the proposal is excellent. It is about hiring native African developers to translate knowledge about Cardano into languages ​​compatible with the inhabitants of the countries of South Africa, Egypt, Nigeria, Kenya and Morocco. This makes perfect sense with the scope of the challenge, since here we are looking to develop projects that are at the same time profitable for our ecosystem, helping Cardano to become a blockchain widely adopted on the continent; just as the projects are expected to benefit Africa. And that will certainly happen here, since, with more content in their native languages, Africans will have easier access to the technical knowledge they need to actively work in our community, whether in Catalyst projects, dApp development, etc. With more professionals converted to Cardano, surely the number of Ada and CNFTs in circulation will increase, just as more Cardano smart contracts and digital wallets will be created. In other words, it is something that has everything to do with what we are looking for, and besides all the project does not start from scratch, since the proponent has already started work with other approaches.
f6_assessments.q1: Using the budget is very simple and clear: the money requested will be 100% used to pay the hired professionals. The team involved is well presented, trust is passed because we have a good amount of information about each of them, we know some data about their pasts, professional histories, we see that there is already a certain understanding about our ecosystem and links that they bought everything that is said. The feasibility problem is the absence of a detailed roadmap, we know what would be done based on the information provided in the impact part; but this should be broken down into phases, into detailed activities. What would be done, how, by whom, when... There is a need to temporally situate ourselves on the beginning, middle and end of each stage. The absence of this knowledge greatly compromises our understanding of the practical application of the project.
f6_assessments.q2: The auditability of progress is great. A lot of information is given about how we would track both tasks and partial successes. The proponent claims that there will be a wallet created especially for the project, so that we can monitor whether the money is being used honestly. We know that there will be content to be shared on social media – for example CardanoMinute on tik tok; from there we can see if the promised contents were actually being created. We also have quantitative data – around 50 students are expected per presentation, feedback would be collected from those involved and so on. That is, on this part, there are no suggestions for improvements to be made. Success is defined by educating students, directing talent to Catalyst so they become active members of the community. It is not so clear how this scenario would be safely demonstrated to our community members. That is, the overall auditability is good, but needs some improvements.

f6_assessments.q0:
The idea is wonderful. Africa is a continent of diverse languages and affiliations and if Cardano would be seeded in Africa then an effort of presenting cardano to the African people in their local dialects will be highly recommended. This ensures that, they understand all that Cardano ecosystem is about. Seeing that the proposer intends hiring 2 additional team members to present educational program (speaks about Cardano, Cardano Foundation, Emurgo and Project Catalyst, as well as demonstrating successful projects like Minswap, Cornucopias and Paribus) and onboard talent to the ecosystem is very crucial to the mission of Cardano that I will say is a big win to Cardano ecosystem. Hence the problem identified aligns with the challenge. The proposer and his team have been winners in previous catalyst rounds and hence I believe their projects are sustainable. That aside, the proposer has indicated that “Depending on the success of this pilot we may approach Catalyst for further funding to continue to reach more students and onboard them to the ecosystem”; it makes it clear that if the need of further funding is required they will return to catalyst, hence the project will be financially sustainable. An education or outreach project as it is has the potential reaching out to a great mass of African students and developers. The project is scalable. 
I believe the proposal makes an impact.
f6_assessments.q1:
As indicated already, the team have been winners in previous project catalyst rounds and considering their relevant skills and links and attachments provided, I believe the team is capable of executing the project. The proposer actually knows his team considering how that there is sufficient details stated for each member. 
The budget of $4,500 has been broken down as though it’s an essay, that’s still okay but it would have been more better to have outlined in bullets so that each sub budget item is on a separate bullet. This helps to create a better understanding of the budget. However, the budget is still understandable and I believe it’s reasonable to achieve the desired outcome.
The plan is rather so brief but however understandable. I believe the proposer employed some high level of synoptic skill to the whole scope of the project. The proposal  has not provided clear timeline and key milestones for delivering the project, and I will say it’s rather unfortunate because it’s difficult to tell how long the project will span and the deliverables and goals at every period. 
The proposer has provided a risk that may arise during the implementation of the project but has not provided a mitigating measure. One other risks that could have been added is timing of Cardano education program delivery so that it does not conflict with lecture periods of the students.
f6_assessments.q2:
The roadmap is brief and has no clear milestones and time horizon, that makes it difficult auditing this aspect of the proposal. However, the proposer has well-thought out metrics/KPIs and I am confident that they are good measures for evaluating success as they indicate a target of 50 students for each presentation. 
There is clarity in the problem described and I believe that the proposed solution is effective to address the problem described. 
I also believe that the project development would be accessible to the community or public considering that there would be a provision of regular reporting to Catalyst via Coordinator and will require that the 2 new recruits participate in the final report video.

solution: Our funded project needs to hire local African speaking developers to promote our educational program to the various countries listed below.
experience: We are a fund 4/6/7/8 Project Catalyst winner.  I manage a team of 5 people who deliver educational content to students and professors. Our MVP has introduced 3,400 students to the Cardano Ecosystem. I am a semi retired university grad with extensive management experience.
